# List of battles 1601–1800__disambig_1

1601–1620

|-

|-

|-
| Polish–Swedish War || Battle of Kokenhausen ||  || 23 June ||
|-
| Eighty Years' War and Anglo-Spanish War || Siege of Ostend ||  || 5 July 1601—20 Sep 1604 || Three-year siege of the city of Ostend.
|-

|-
| Battle of Coire Na Creiche
|-

|-

|-

|-

|-

|-

|-
| Eighty Years' War and Anglo-Spanish War || Siege of 's-Hertogenbosch ||  || 1–27 Nov || Unsuccessful Dutch attempt to capture the city of 's-Hertogenbosch.
|-
| Nine Years' War || Battle of Castlehaven ||  || 6 Dec || British naval victory, wherein five of the six Spanish Armada ships are destroyed or captured, while Great Britain did not lose any.
|-
| Dutch–Portuguese War || Battle of Bantam ||  || 27 Dec || Portuguese forced to retreat from a fleet of five Dutch ships, despite having eight galleons and several fustas.
|-
| rowspan="11" | 1602 || Nine Years' War || Battle of Kinsale ||  || 3 Jan || Campaign headed by O'Neill, O'Donnell and other Irish lords at the climax of the war.
|-
| rowspan="2" | Polish–Swedish War || Siege of Fellin || rowspan="2" |  || 25 March—17 May || Polish and Lithuanian forces led by Grand Crown Hetman Jan Zamoyski besiege the Swedish-held town of Fellin.
|-
| Siege of Weissenstein || 31 May—30 Sep || Polish-Lithuanian army of 2,000 troops besiege Weissenstein. The Swedes capitulate on 30 September.
|-
| Anglo-Spanish War || Battle of Sesimbra Bay ||  || 3 June || Between an English naval expeditionary force of five galleons and a Spanish fleet of 11 galleys, a large carrack and help from a fort and shore batteries.
|-
| Nine Years' War || Siege of Dunboy ||  || 5–18 June || Battle between the Irish and English crown at Dunboy Castle, a stronghold of Donal Cam O'Sullivan Beare.
|-
| Polish–Swedish War || Battle of Reval ||  || 30 June || Polish break Swedish lines at  Tallinn.
|-
| Nine Years' War || Burning of Dungannon ||  || June || Beginning of the final stage of Tyrone's Rebellion.
|-
| rowspan="2" | Eighty Years' War and Anglo-Spanish War || Siege of Grave ||  || 18 July—20 Sep || Netherlands and Great Britain capture Grave from Spain.
|-
| Battle of the Narrow Seas || / || 3–4 Oct || An English and Dutch fleet of nine galleons, carracks and galiots intercept and attack six Spanish galleys.
|-
| || L'Escalade ||  || 11–12 Dec || Failed attempt by Catholic Savoy to conquer Protestant Geneva, resulting in a peace treaty in July 1603.
|-
| rowspan="2" | Scottish clan wars || Battle of Morar || rowspan="2" |  || || Clan battle near Loch Morar between the Clan MacDonell of Glengarry and the Clan Mackenzie, who were supported by the Clan Ross.
|-
| rowspan="8" | 1603 || Battle of Glen Fruin || 7 Feb || Clan battle between the Clan Gregor and the Clan Colquhoun and their respective allies.
|-
| Anglo-Spanish War || Battle of Puerto Caballos ||  || 17 Feb || Successful British campaign to capture Puerto Caballos.
|-
| Polish–Swedish War || Battle of Rakvere ||  || 5 March || Jan Karol Chodkiewicz defeats the Swedish relief force of 2,000 with 1,000 men.
|-
| Anglo-Spanish War || Raid on Santiago de Cuba ||  || 12 May || Santiago de Cuba is attacked and sacked by English privateers near the end of the war.
|-
| Eighty Years' War || Battle of Sluis ||  || 26 May || Spanish fleet of eight galleys is defeated by the Dutch fleet of three men of war, two galleys and several smaller vessels. The Spanish commander Spinola dies.
|-
| Long Turkish War || Battle of Brașov ||  || 17 July || Wallachia-Habsburg troops led by Șerban fight Transylvanian-Moldavian troops led by Székely. Monarchy victory.
|-
| Ottoman–Safavid war || Capture of Tabriz ||  || 1–21 Oct || Tabriz is captured by Shah Abbas I's Safavid army from the Ottoman Turks after 20 days fighting.
|-
| Long Turkish War || Siege of Buda ||  || 20 Sep—20 Nov || The Holy Roman Empire fails to capture Buda from the Ottoman Empire.
|-
| rowspan="6" | 1604 || Eighty Years' War and Anglo-Spanish War || Siege of Sluis ||  || 19 May—19 Aug || Dutch and English armies take Cadzand, Aardenburg and IJzendijke in the Spanish Netherlands, leading to a siege of the Spanish-held inland port of Sluis.
|-
| Anglo-Spanish War || Battle of the Gulf of Cadiz || / || 7 Aug || Two  Spanish galleons engage two English privateers plundering shipping lanes and villages around the Gulf of Cádiz.
|-
| Polish–Swedish War || Battle of Weissenstein ||  || 25 Sep || Polish-Lithuanian victory over Sweden.
|-
| Polish–Russian War || Battle of Novhorod-Siverskyi ||  || 31 Dec || First major battle of False Dmitry I against Boris Godunov.
|-
| Ottoman–Safavid war || Battle of Urmia ||  || || Decisive Safavid victory over the Ottoman Empire.
|-
| || Battle of Lješkopolje ||  || || 12,000-strong army clashes with 400 Montenegrins in Lješanska nahija. The battle lasted through the night; at dawn, Montenegrins launched a sudden charge, surprising the enemy and causing a retreat.
|-
| rowspan="6" | 1605 || rowspan="2" | Polish–Muscovite War || Battle of Dobrynichi || rowspan="2" |  || 21 Jan || Pretender to the Russian throne is defeated, but escapes.
|-
| Siege of Kromy || Feb—May || Last major clash between Godunov's troops and False Dmitry I's.
|-
| Polish–Swedish War || Battle of Kircholm ||  || 27 Sep || Polish hussars cavalry is outnumbered and defeated by the Swedish.
|-
| rowspan="2" | Eighty Years' War || Siege of Wachtendonk || rowspan="2" |  ||  8–28 Oct || Spain captures Wachtendonk from the Netherlands.
|-
| Battle of Mülheim || 9 Oct || Spain defeats the Netherlands.
|-
| Ottoman–Safavid war || Battle of Sufiyan ||  || 6 Nov || Safavid victory over the Ottoman Empire.
|-
| Mughal-Persian Wars || Siege of Kandahar ||  || Nov 1605—Jan 1606 || Safavid governor of Herat moves to recapture Kandahar while the Mughals are distracted by the death of Emperor Akbar.
|-

|-

|-

|-

|-
| Eighty Years' War || Siege of Rheinberg ||  || 22 Aug—1 Oct || Spain captures Rheinberg from the Netherlands.
|-

|-

| Zebrzydowski Rebellion || Battle of Guzów ||  || 6 July || Polish Royalists defeat the Zebrzydowski rebels.
|-
| Polish–Russian War || Battle of Kozelsk ||  || 8 Oct || The first victory of False Dmitry II against the government of Tsar Vasili IV Shiusk.
|-
|-
| || Raid on Bone ||  || || Raid by the Tuscan Order of St. Stephen against the Ottoman town of Bône.
|-

|-

|-

|-
| Battle of Medvezhiy Brod || June || False Dmitry II's troops defeat the Lisowczyks.
|-

|-

| Battle of Salis ||  || 23–24 March || Polish ambush and defeat Swedes heading towards Riga.
|-
| Polish–Muscovite War || Battle of Kamenka ||  || 25 May ||

| Battle of Tver ||  21–23 July
|-

| Siege of Smolensk || 23 Sep 1609—13 June 1611 || Polish capture Smolensk.

| Battle of Troitsko ||  || 28 Oct ||

|-

|-

|-
| Spanish–Ottoman wars || Action off La Goulette ||  || Dec || Spanish privateer squadron under Ribera defeat a Tunisian fleet.
|-
| || Siege of Braunschweig ||  || || Duke Friedrich Ulrich lays siege to Braunschweig until Hanseatic and Dutch relief forces arrive.

| Kakhetian Uprising || Battle of Tsitsamuri ||  || || Kingdom of Kakheti battles the Safavid domination. Kakheti victory.

| rowspan="4" | 1616 || Ahom-Mughal conflicts || Battle of Samdhara ||  || Jan || Ahom kingdom victory over the Mughal Empire.
|-

|-
| || Battle of Toppur ||  || Late 1616 || Disintegration of the already declining Vijayanagara Empire. One of the largest battles in the history of South Asia.
|-
| || Siege of Vercelli ||  || || Spanish forces capture the Savoyard fortress.
|-
| rowspan="2" | 1617 || Eighty Years' War || Second Battle of Playa Honda ||  || 14–15 April || Spanish victory in the Philippines outside Manila Bay. This naval battle decided the future of the Philippines for centuries to come.
|-
|  || Sacking of Saint Thomas of Guyana ||  || || Raleigh's second El Dorado expeditions sack the second settlement of Santo Tomé de Guayana.
|-
| rowspan="5" | 1618 || Polish–Muscovite War || Battle of Mozhaysk ||  || Jan-July || Precursor to the Siege of Moscow.
|-
| Thirty Years' War || Siege of Pilsen ||  || 19 Sep—21 Nov || The first major battle of the war. The Protestant victory under Mansfeld and the subsequent capture of the city enlarged the Bohemian Revolt.
|-
| || Battle of Orynin ||  || 28 Sep || Polish forces face Crimean Tatars from Budjak near Orynin in Podolia.
|-
| Polish–Russian War and Polish–Muscovite War || Siege of Moscow ||  || 2–11 Oct || Władysław's last major military action of the war. Russians forced to cede some of its land in the Truce of Deulino.
|-

| rowspan="5" | 1619 || Manchu conquest of China || Battle of Sarhū ||  || 14–18 April || The Manchus defeat the Ming.
|-
| || Siege of Batavia Castle ||  || 30 May || Coen sieges Jakarta with the intent of moving the base of the Dutch East India Company to Java from Bantam. The Mataram, under whose influence Jakarta fell, was opposed to this and resisted strongly.

|-
| Battle of Wisternitz || 5 Aug || Bohemia defeats a Habsburg army.
|-
| Battle of Humenné ||  || 22–23 Nov || Poland defeats a pro-Bohemia Transylvanian army in the Commonwealth's only battle of the war.
|-

|-
| Moldavian Magnate Wars and Polish–Ottoman War || Battle of Cecora ||  || 17 Sep—7 Oct || Ottoman Turks assisted by Crimean Tatars defeat the Polish army in Moldavia. Also known as the Battle of Țuțora.
|-

|-
| Polish-Ottoman War and Cossack raids || Cossack raid on Istanbul ||  || || A campaign of the Zaporozhian Cossacks to the capital of the Ottoman Empire.
